subject: using abstract classes to test interfaces
msgSnippet: Hi.  I ve got a system that is structured as follows.  I ve got an interface Widget .  I ve got three implementors of Widget .  I want test all three
messageBody:
Hi. I've got a system that is structured as follows. I've got an
interface "Widget". I've got three implementors of "Widget". I want test
all three implementations, so I write a class, "TestWidget":

public class TestWidget extends TestCase {
public abstract Widget getWidget();
private Wiget toTest;
protected Widget setup(){
toTest = getWidget();
}

public testOne(){
toTest.doSometing();
}
}

Now I specialize the construct like so:
public class TestWidget1 extends TestWidget {
public Widget1 getWidget(){ return new Widget1(); }
}

I do this for my other implementors. The problem is, when I add
"TestWidget1", "TestWidget2", etc, to my suite, the "test*" methods are
never executed! I assume this is because reflection is only occuring on
the instantiated class and not it's superclasses?

Does anyone have any thoughts about this - is it a bug or a feature, is
there a clean workaound, etc?

Thanks!
Dale Martin
